body:
I am also facing the same issue during stage_1 training:

RuntimeError: 
        An attempt has been made to start a new process before the
        current process has finished its bootstrapping phase.

        This probably means that you are not using fork to start your
        child processes and you have forgotten to use the proper idiom
        in the main module:

            if __name__ == '__main__':
                freeze_support()
                ...

        The "freeze_support()" line can be omitted if the program
        is not going to be frozen to produce an executable.

@jchhuang @RamyaRaghuraman Actually, as written in the paper, we used frozen resnet 152 feature extractor for the places experiments. The first reason is that finetuning resnet 152 requires large gpu resource, which we don't have. Second, as I explained in https://github.com/zhmiao/OpenLongTailRecognition-OLTR/issues/22#issuecomment-516685058 self attention module and meta embedding module require initialization. Since the feature extractor is already imagenet pretrained, so self attention module won't be affected too much. However, in stage 1, we are still training classifier module with an additional fc layer. The memory is initialized using the feature after the fc, and the meta embedding was initialized using the stage 1 pretrained classifier. So the training of stage 1 is not meaningless.
@zhmiao Thank you for your reply. I understand that the stage 1 training is required, but I am still not able to overcome the stated "freeze_support()" error. Is there a work around for this?
@RamyaRaghuraman Could you be a little bit more specific on the error?

@zhmiao I have attached the entire output for stage_1 training. I am using only 1 GPU but I do not know where the multiprocessing error comes from.

@RamyaRaghuraman Thanks for posting the error message. It seems to be a problem of running pytorch on windows instead of frozen weights. Here is an issue from pytorch official repo: https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/5858#issue-306187894 . I will close this issue and open a new one about this (https://github.com/zhmiao/OpenLongTailRecognition-OLTR/issues/29#issue-478007805). We do not have a windows machine to test it for now. I think we will try to get one and see if it is possible to reproduce. Thanks.

issue.title: Running on windows

repository.name: OpenLongTailRecognition-OLTR
repository.description: Pytorch implementation for "Large-Scale Long-Tailed Recognition in an Open World" (CVPR 2019 ORAL)

issue.body: It seems there would be some problem running the code on windows, as discussed in https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/5858#issue-306187894 . By far we do not have any solutions to this issue, and it seems to be a pytorch issue. We will test it out when we have a windows machine.

body:
> 
> 
> @jchhuang @RamyaRaghuraman Actually, as written in the paper, we used frozen resnet 152 feature extractor for the places experiments. The first reason is that finetuning resnet 152 requires large gpu resource, which we don't have. Second, as I explained in [#22 (comment)](https://github.com/zhmiao/OpenLongTailRecognition-OLTR/issues/22#issuecomment-516685058) self attention module and meta embedding module require initialization. Since the feature extractor is already imagenet pretrained, so self attention module won't be affected too much. However, in stage 1, we are still training classifier module with an additional fc layer. The memory is initialized using the feature after the fc, and the meta embedding was initialized using the stage 1 pretrained classifier. So the training of stage 1 is not meaningless.

Hi, I don't agree this explain. In my understanding, the dimension of centroid is num_class*num_feature, however, the output of fc is a 1*num_class vector, their size are not matched, how can a vector initialize a matrix？
